revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian | image = Martin Mull.jpg | caption = Performing at the Boarding House in San Francisco, 1976 | birth_name = Martin Eugene Mull | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1943|8|18}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | nationality = American | education = [[New Canaan High School]] | alma_mater = [[Rhode Island School of Design]] | spouse = {{marriage|Kristin Johnson
|1972|1978|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Sandra Baker
|1978|1981|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|[[Wendy Haas]]
|1982}} | children = 1 | website = }} '''Martin Eugene Mull'''http://mivoice.flightpathcreative.com/pdfs/issue-31-5.pdf (born August 18, 1943){{cite news |title= Today in history |date= 2014-08-18 |url= http://nyti.ms/1t9nSQB |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |agency= [[Associated Press]] |accessdate= 2014-08-18}} is an [[United States|American]] actor, comedian, and singer who has appeared in many television and film roles. He is also a [[Painting|painter]] and recording artist. As an actor, he first became known in his role on ''[[Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman]]'' and its spin-off ''[[Fernwood 2 Night]]''. Among his other notable roles are Colonel Mustard in the 1985 film ''[[Clue (film)|Clue]]'', Leon Carp on ''[[Roseanne]]'', Willard Kraft on ''[[Sabrina the Teenage Witch (1996 TV series)|Sabrina, the Teenage Witch]]'', Vlad Plasmius on ''[[Danny Phantom]]'', and Gene Parmesan on ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]''. ==Early years and education== Mull was born in [[Chicago]], the son of Betty, an actress and director, and Harold Mull, a carpenter.{{cite news| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19791207&id=PlBSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dnwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6807,6524252| newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]| title=Martin Mull has interest in art, penchant for humor| first=Robert| last=Ely| date=December 7, 1979}} He moved with his family to [[North Ridgeville, Ohio]], when he was two years old. They stayed there until he was 15 years old, when his family moved to [[New Canaan, Connecticut]], where he attended and graduated from public high school.{{cite web | url=http://www.pattersonandassociates.com/bios/Martin_Mull/index.html | publisher=Patterson & Associates | title=Martin Mull | accessdate=2006-09-17}} He studied painting and went on to graduate from the [[Rhode Island School of Design]] with a [[Bachelor of Fine Arts]] and a [[Master of Fine Arts]] in painting. ==Career== ===Acting career=== Mull's first well known acting role was as Garth Gimble in the 1976 television nighttime [[Absurdist fiction|absurdist]] [[soap opera]] ''[[Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman]]''. This led to work in the [[spin-off (media)|spin-off]] comedy talk shows ''[[Fernwood 2 Night]]'' (1977) and ''[[America 2-Night]]'' (1978), in which he played talk show host Barth Gimble (Garth Gimble's twin brother), opposite [[Fred Willard]], as sidekick Jerry Hubbard. In 1979, he appeared in the ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'' episode ''Hollywood Calling''. Mull created, wrote for and starred in the short-lived 1984 [[CBS]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Domestic Life (TV series)|Domestic Life]]'', with [[Megan Follows]] playing his teenaged daughter. In one episode of ''[[The Golden Girls]]'', he played a [[hippie]] who was afraid of the outside world. He had a long-running role as Leon Carp, Roseanne Conner's gay boss (and later business partner) on the TV series ''[[Roseanne]]''. During the 1980s, Mull played a supporting role in the film ''[[Mr. Mom]]'', and starred in a series of commercials for [[Michelob]] and [[Pizza Hut]], and in a series of television and [[radio]] commercials for [[Red Roof Inn]]. He appeared in the [[Pecos Bill]] episode of the [[Shelley Duvall]] TV series ''[[Tall Tales & Legends]]''. He also did the voice of [[Vlad Masters/Vlad Plasmius]], the main villain in ''[[Danny Phantom]]''. Mull has appeared as a guest star on the game show ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'', appearing as the center square in the show's final season, from 2003 to 2004. In late 2004 and in 2013's Netflix-produced Season 4, he portrayed Gene Parmesan, a [[private investigator]], on the TV series ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]''. During 2008 and 2009, Mull guest starred in two episodes of the television series ''[[Gary Unmarried]]'' as Allison's father.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/showatch/gary-unmarried/ |title=FutonCritic.com page on ''Gary Unmarried'' |publisher=Thefutoncritic.com |date=2009-01-07 |accessdate=2016-08-26}} Mull also starred in the Fox sitcom ''[[Dads (2013 TV series)|Dads]]''. [[File:Martin Mull (footprints in cement).jpg|thumb|A caricature of Martin Mull in front of [[Hollywood Hills Amphitheater]] at [[Walt Disney World]]'s [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]] theme park.]] ===Musical career=== Mull broke into show business as a songwriter, penning [[Jane Morgan]]'s 1970 country single, ''A Girl Named Johnny Cash'', which peaked at #61 on Billboard's country charts. Shortly thereafter, he began his own recording career. Throughout the 1970s, and especially in the first half of the decade, Mull was best known as a musical comedian, performing satirical and humorous songs both live and in-studio recordings. Notable live gigs included opening for [[Randy Newman]] and [[Sandy Denny]] at [[Boston Symphony Hall]] in 1973;{{cite web|url=http://www.learningace.com/doc/5522258/4b3a3c254d6c5346578e77192425c261/n24 |title=The Tech, (May 11, 1973) |publisher=Learningace.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-26}} [[Frank Zappa]] at [[Austin, Texas|Austin]]'s [[Armadillo World Headquarters]] in 1973; Billy Joel in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania in 1974; and for [[Bruce Springsteen]] at the Shady Grove Music Fair in [[Gaithersburg, Maryland]], in October 1974. His self-titled debut Album, released by Capricorn in 1972, featured many noteworthy musicians, including [[Ramblin' Jack Elliott]], [[Levon Helm]] from [[The Band]], Keith Spring of [[NRBQ]] and [[Libby Titus]].{{cite web|url=http://theband.hiof.no/albums/martin_mull.html |title=The History of the Band, (March 2013) |publisher=Theband.hiof.no |date= |accessdate=2016-08-26}} ==="Dancing about Architecture"=== [[Elvis Costello]] and Gary Sperrazza attribute the remark, "Writing about music is like dancing about architecture" to Martin Mull.{{cite web | url=http://quoteinvestigator.com/2010/11/08/writing-about-music/ | publisher=Quote Investigator | title=Writing About Music | accessdate=2012-04-10}}{{cite web | url=http://www.freakonomics.com/2010/12/30/quotes-uncovered-dancing-about-architecture/ | publisher=Freakonomics | title=Quotes Uncovered: Dancing About Architecture | accessdate=2012-04-10}} ===Artistic career=== Mull has been a painter since the 1970s, and has work appear in group and solo exhibits. He participated in the June 15, 1971 exhibit "Flush with the Walls" in the men's room of the Boston Museum of Art to protest the lack of contemporary and local art in the museum.{{cite news|last=Cook|first=Greg|title=Local Artists Commemorate -and re-stage -a legendary protest|url=http://thephoenix.com/boston/arts/122501-local-artists-commemorate-and-re-stage-a-leg/|accessdate=9 July 2013|newspaper=The Phoenix|date=June 15, 2011}} His work often combines [[photorealist]] painting, and the [[pop art]] and [[collage]] styles.[http://www.artnet.com/artists/martin-mull/ Martin Mull], Artnet He published a book of some of his paintings, titled ''Paintings Drawings and Words'', in 1995. One of his paintings was used on the cover for the 2008 [[Joyce Carol Oates]] novel ''[[My Sister, My Love (novel)|My Sister, My Love]]''.[http://furioushorses.com/2009/04/01/format-follies-pt-3/ Format Follies, Pt. 3], Christopher Currie, ''Furious Horses'' (blog), April 1, 2009 Another painting, owned by [[Steve Martin]] titled ''After Dinner Drinks'' (2008), was used for the cover of ''[[Love Has Come for You]]'', an album by Steve Martin and [[Edie Brickell]].Neale, April (2013). "[http://www.monstersandcritics.com/music/news/article_1714215.php Steve Martin's 'Love has Come For You' celebrates Martin Mull's artistry, tour dates (VIDEO)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525232931/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/music/news/article_1714215.php |date=2014-05-25 }}", ''MonstersAndCritics.com''. ==Personal life== Twice divorced, Mull is married to singer [[Wendy Haas]]. The two have a daughter, Maggie.{{IMDb name|id=0611898|section=bio|name=Martin Mull}}Wojciechowski, Michele "Wojo" (2013). "[http://parade.condenast.com/168758/michelewojciechowski/foxs-dads-star-martin-mull-the-accidental-comedian/ FOX’s Dads Star Martin Mull: The Accidental Comedian]", ''Parade.CondeNast.com''."[http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/martin-mull/bio/164903 Martin Mull Biography]", ''TvGuide.com''.Lavin, Cheryl (1994). "[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-09-04/features/9409040315_1_stanley-elkin-mull-kicked Martin Mull]", ''ChicagoTribune.com''. In a 2010 interview on ''[[The Green Room with Paul Provenza]]'', Mull identifies himself as an [[agnostic]], saying "I certainly don't begrudge someone else their choice to follow whatever they do, it's just for me, it doesn't make a lot of sense. I think more harm has come to this planet through organized religion, probably, than any single situation that we've invented."{{Citation|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ijCXUVj3ea0 | title=The Green Room with Paul Provenza | date=July 15, 2010}} ==Filmography== ===Films=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! (1973) *''Normal'' (1974) *''In The Soop With Martin Mull'' (also with: Ed Wise and Les Daniels) (1974) *''Days Of Wine And Neuroses'' (1975) *''I'm Everyone I've Ever Loved'' (1977) *''No Hits, Four Errors- The Best Of Martin Mull'' (1977) *''Sex & Violins'' (1978) *''Near Perfect/Perfect'' (1979) *''Mulling it Over- A Musical Ouvre-View of Martin Mull'' (1998) == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|Martin Mull}} *{{IMDb name|611898|Martin Mull}} *[http://www.nndb.com/people/494/000024422/ NNDB page for Martin Mull] *[http://www.artnet.com/artist/12223/martin-mull.html Martin Mull on Artnet] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mull, Martin}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:20th-century American musicians]] [[Category:20th-century American painters]] [[Category:American male painters]] [[Category:21st-century American male actors]] [[Category:21st-century American musicians]] [[Category:21st-century American painters]] [[Category:Male actors from Chicago]] [[Category:American agnostics]] [[Category:American comedy musicians]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American male voice actors]] [[Category:People from New Canaan, Connecticut]] [[Category:People from North Ridgeville, Ohio]] [[Category:Rhode Island School of Design alumni]] [[Category:Comedians from Ohio]] [[Category:Comedians from Illinois]]
